citation.article-title: Brevinema andersonii gen. nov., sp. nov., an infectious spirochete isolated from the short-tailed shrew (Blarina brevicauda) and the white-footed mouse (Peromyscus leucopus).

p.s: Brevinema (Brev. i. ne' ma. L. adj. brevis, short; Gr. n. nema, thread; N.L. neut. n. Brevinema, a short thread.)
The following description is based on our data and data obtained from previous studies (1, 5, 12, 13, 17).
Cells are flexible and helical; they are 0.2 to 0.3 μm in diameter and 4 to 5 μm long.
One to two waves occur, and the irregular wavelengths of the spirochete cells range from 2 to 3 μm.
Ultrastructurally, the cells possess traits that are typical of spirochetes.
They possess an outer envelope, a protoplasmic cylinder, and sheathed periplasmic flagella in a 1-2-1 arrangement.
Cytoplasmic tubules have not been observed.
Cells are motile and exhibit flexing, rotational, and translational movements at 30°C.
Cells stain negatively by Gram reaction.
While cells are visible by dark-field or phase-contrast microscopy, they cannot be seen when bright-field microscopy is used.

Brevinema strains have unique single-base nucleotide signatures at positions 52 359 (G⋄C) and 783⋄799 (U⋄A) which differentiate them from other major spirochete phylogenetic groups. Brevinema andersonii CT11616T, FS47, and MV116 have a distinguishing 16s rRNA sequence corresponding to positions 724 to 750 in E. coli (5'-GGCAGCUACCUAUGCUAAGAUUGACGC-3‘).

Strains have been isolated from blood and other tissues of short-tailed shrews (Blarina brevicauda) and white-footed mice (Peromyscus leucopus) and are infectious for laboratory mice and Syrian hamsters.
The type species is Brevinema andersonii.
